note: also in American history) from Harvard University in 1921. That same year she moved to Minneapolis to become curator of manuscripts for the Minnesota Historical Society, a position she held for 25 years.
title: One of seven children, her brief biography redefines the word “striver.” She graduated from Smith College in 1917 with an A.B. in American literature just as America entered the Great War. A year later she became a history major, completing work on a master’s degree at Radcliffe College in 1918 and subsequently received her Ph.D

A biologist and systematic zoologist for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service from 1918–1961, Viola Shelly Shantz (1895–1977) was one of the founding members of the American Society of Mammalogists and coauthored a comprehensive catalog of the mammal specimens in the collections of the United States National Museum

Women in Museums: A Progress Report

note: EPILOGUE Gender, Power, Influence, and Responsibility
title: He for She

note: • Look outside the field for ideas, information, and solutions, and share them with memberships and boards of trustees. Model the work of organizations like the American Library Association, American Historical Association, as well as museum organizations in the United Kingdom and Canada.
title: • Make gender equity a criterion for AAM accreditation, in the AASLH STePs Program, and in other voluntary recognition and development programs. • Develop and promote standards for what makes a great museum workplace culture. Incorporate these standards into existing self-assessment and recognition programs. • Create and support gender equity task forces and groups focusing on leadership training/advancement for women. • Develop and promulgate core competencies/qualities for leadership and management positions. • Collect and publish better data about the museum workforce; support and publish research by others. • Lobby the Department of Labor and the Census Bureau for more detailed statistics about representation and earnings of women within the museum profession and share with memberships. • Encourage and participate in networking among allied professional associations to address equity, diversity, and inclusion challenges

The IMLS, in collaboration with the professional associations and foundation support, needs to fund a current comprehensive, comparative equity and diversity study for museums, libraries, and archives. • Make human resource policies and access to professional HR support part of any capacity-building funding program
